events.name: NoSQL Cutting Through the Hype & Pervasive Analytics: Building a Data Strategy
events.description: We are lucky to have two great speakers visiting Singapore on the same day, so we have moved the April meeting date to coincide with their visit to Singapore. Matt Brandwein, Director of Product Marketing at Cloudera will be speaking on Pervasive Analytics: Building a Data Strategy • How is data driving change? • Where are the opportunities, across industries? • What is required to gain value from data? • How can you get started today? Akmal B. Chaudhri will be speaking on "Cutting through the NoSQL database hoopla and hype" Today, there are thought to be over 150 commercial and open source NoSQL database products. Often, these products are divided into four broad categories: key-value stores, column stores, document stores and graph stores. Increasingly, some products are combining several of these categories together into what are called multi-model database systems. Whilst the market for NoSQL database systems today is still very small and thought to be around 2% of the SQL market, the technology has attracted interest from organizations looking to solve new business problems. However, since it is still an emerging technology, careful consideration is required in finding the relevant developer skills and choosing the right product. This presentation will discuss these issues in greater detail. In particular, it will focus on some of the leading NoSQL database products and discuss their architectures and suitability for different problems. Akmal's Bio: Akmal B. Chaudhri is an Independent Consultant, specializing in Big Data, NoSQL and NewSQL database technologies. He has over 25 years experience in IT and has previously held roles as a developer, consultant, product strategist and technical trainer. He has worked for several blue-chip companies, such as Reuters and IBM and also the Big Data startups Hortonworks (Hadoop) and DataStax (Cassandra NoSQL Database). He has worked extensively on worldwide developer relations programs at IBM and worldwide university relations and academic initiative programs at Informix and IBM. He has regularly presented at many international conferences and served on the program committees for a number of major conferences and workshops. He has published and presented widely on Java, XML and Database systems and edited or co-edited 10 books. He holds a BSc (1st Class Hons.) in Computing and Information Systems, MSc in Business Systems Analysis and Design and a PhD in Computer Science. He is a Member of the British Computer Society (MBCS) and a Chartered IT Professional (CITP). Website: about.me/akmalchaudhri Twitter: @akmalchaudhri
events.location: Paypal, #14-01, 1 Temasek Boulevard, Singapore 039192

events.name: April Meetup
events.description: Hi folks! We look forward to having you join us for our April meetup, on the 28th, 7.00pm at NDC (Level 2). We're still looking for speakers! Ping us (Anna or Winston) if you'd like to do a 10-15min talk or 5 Random Ruby Tips. We're also counting down to RDRC - Early bird tickets are now on sale :) Have you bought yours? See you on the 28th! Venue: IDA Labs Level 2 @ National Design Centre, 111 Middle Road, #02-04, 188969, Singapore -------------- 1. "Open 'sesame' - The dangers of open-uri and remote code execution" Ted Johansson / @drenmi 2. "Decorator in Ruby" Kevin Tran 3. "5 Random Ruby Tips" Grzegorz Witek / @arnvald * Hot Picks - This is a 5-10 minute session during which anyone can stand up and say something interesting! -------------- Would you like to speak at our future meetups? You could share about your startup technology stack, your new RubyGem, or your opinions on best practices, so that people can get to know how awesome you are! We also have a 5min section on "5 Random Ruby Tips" that you can volunteer for - I am sure you must have came across some interesting Ruby nuggets in the last month right? So don't be shy! Step forward and share your knowledge! Ping Winston @winstonyw or winstonyw@gmail.com, or Anna @anna_fil or annafil@gmail.com. See you all soon! -------------- Job Postings -------------- Are you looking for Rubyists? Do you have a job posting? Email us a blurb (< 50 words) + link and we'll put it here. 1. CareerFoundry CareerFoundry.com teaches online, mentored courses in Full-Stack Web Development. We are looking to hire experienced and passionate web developers all over the world to join our mentor community. As a mentor, you'll help define the next generation of tech talent by guiding students on their path to become full-stack web developers. For more details about mentoring and to apply, please visit www.careerfoundry.com/me­ntoring. Contact: Blake Farha, Mentor Advisor blake@careerfoundry­.com 2. ReferralCandy Hi! We're looking for Full Stack Software Engineers to grow the product team! Join us to work on challenging problems in a flexible result-oriented environment. You'll be joining a small team that cares about people and stuff we do, and have the opportunity to improve daily workflows and lead feature development. See you soon! http://www.referralcandy.com/jobs -------------- Thank You, Sponsors! Food and Drinks: Venue:
events.location: IDA Labs Level 2 @ National Design Centre, 111 Middle Road, #02-04, Singapore 188969

events.name: Book Club: High Performance Websites
events.description: The weekly SingaporeJS book club is back! This time we will be reading the book High Performance Websites together and creating interactive exercises to go along with it. This will be the last week for High Performance Websites. We will quickly cover the last few chapters of the book: • Rule 8: Make JavaScript and CSS External • Rule 9: Reduce DNS Lookups • Rule 10: Minify JavaScript • Rule 11: Avoid Redirects • Rule 12: Remove Duplicate Scripts • Rule 13: Configure ETags • Rule 14: Make Ajax Cacheable Format for the book club: 1. Buy the book and read the Chapter(s) BEFORE the meetup. 2. Pick an Item from the Chapter and prepare some discussion points and/or questions. 3. Let the rest of us know which Item you picked by leaving a comment. We will be reading at Tim & Wei's residence at Tanjong Katong Road. Door opens at 7.00pm. Feel free to ask questions in the SingaporeJS gitter room: https://gitter.im/SingaporeJS/discussions See you there!
events.location: Tim & Wei's Residence, 244A Tanjong Katong Road, Singapore

events.name: EdTech Meetup #1 - EdTech Ecosystem Panel & Video for Better Edu. Outcomes
events.description:
Come join and network with the local EdTech community for EdTech Asia’s innaugural and free event. The evening will feature a 20 minute presentation titled Leveraging VIdeo for Better Educational Outcomes followed by a 40 minute panel discussion on Local and Regional EdTech Ecosystems: Challenges and Opportunities. Ample time for networking will be provided. 
Panelists: 
Elisha Tan is an Ecosystem Builder at Tech in Asia. She helps build startup ecosystems in Asia by providing the right resources and opportunities to founders, investors, accelerators and incubators. Prior to working at TIA, Elisha foudned Learnemy, an online marketplace where you can take in-person classes from local experts in Singapore.  Adrian Lim is the Deputy Director at IDA of Singapore where he leads a dynamic team to look at how we can work with the Education Technology industries to develop innovative and new ideas and applications in schools to enhance learning and teaching in the 21st century. Leslie Loh is active in the education startup investment space within the Asian region. He is also the founder of Tien Academy, a blended MOOC model to deliver entrepreneurship training in Singapore and across the region and acting Chairman of Lithan Education, a cooperative education provider for professional communities in Asia through competency based education and work integrated experiential learning.

events.name: April Meetup
events.description: April is upon us and so is the April meetup! This meetup will be on the 30th of April at 7pm at some yet to be decided location. The venue is Hackerspace SG at King George's Avenue. We're looking for 2-3 15-20 minutes talk. PyCon Singapore will be on the June 17th to 19th and tickets are available at the website, please check it out and attend! https://pycon.sg/ -------------- Thanks to Michael from Engineers.sg the talks from the last meetup is available on YouTube do check them out: 1. Getting started with testing using Pytest and Mock - PythonSG Meetup by Gabe Hollombe 2. Developing real time applications in Django with Websockets - PythonSG Meetup by Gerald Goh 3. How to learn and be productive with Python3 in a week - PythonSG Meetup by Chris 4. Three Python tips - PythonSG Meetup by Martin Brochhaus And a link to Bitmazk's Github as mentioned in the video. -------------- Talks 1. "Why should you do behavior/test driven development" by Björn Andersson Being a crimson speckled pythonista that dabbles with Ruby I've noticed that the amount of people that do TDD in the Python community is a lot fewer than in the Ruby community. With this talk I would therefore like to share some reasons that I think doing TDD might help you get things done faster and better. How it all helps me feel more safe when requirements changes and ensuring those pesky bugs stays fixed. This will mostly be a talk of why, for the how I recommend Gabe's excellent intro to Pytest from the last meetup linked above. 2. How I built a SFTP service using Paramiko by Steve 3. 4. "Python tips / Module of the month" by …you? -------------- Would you like to speak at this or a future meetups? You could share about your technology stack, how you solved a problem, your new library, or your opinions on best practices, so that people can get to know how awesome you are! 5 Python tips is a small segment at the end of meetup where you can share some things that make your Python life easier. A newly discovered core module, a library or some command line tool that makes your life better and/or easier. So don't be shy! Step forward and share your knowledge! For speaking please contact Björn, @gaqzi or <ba@sanitarium.se>, or Victor <icyisamu@gmail.com> See you all soon! -------------- Job Postings Are you looking for Pythonista? Do you have a job posting? Email us a blurb (< 50 words) + link and we'll put it here. -------------- Venue sponsor
events.location: Hackerspace.SG, 344B King George's Ave, King George's Building, Singapore

events.name: Canonical’s 2015 OpenStack Roadshow - Singapore
events.description:
At this roadshow event, Mark Shuttleworth and the senior architects of Canonical's Openstack strategy will present the product roadmap and exchange views with cloud architects and executive sponsors for private cloud initiatives across the enterprise landscape, globally. The tour has already passed through North and South America, Europe and is now coming to Asia. It is open by invitation to those shaping private cloud strategy in select companies. 
  
Join us if Openstack is a real goal in your next 12 months. Topics will include: 

Software-defined network (SDN) evaluation strategies
Use of OpenStack for Network Function Virtualisation and other telco use cases
Security considerations for banking and other regulated industries
Scale-out storage options like Ceph and Lustre
Integration with existing infrastructure such as SANs and VMware
The intersection of industrial HPC and Openstack
Hyperdense hosting with KVM virtual machines and LXD system containers

 
  
Schedule: 10.00am: Coffee and registration  
10.30am: Presentations commence 
12.30am: Presentations end 
 Sign up to the Singapore event here or check out the full list of roadshow locations.
events.location: Marina Bay Sands Singapore, , 10 Bayfront Ave, Singapore 018956

events.name: More with LeSS: And Introduction to Large-Scale Scrum
events.description:
LeSS is a lightweight (agile) framework for scaling Scrum to more than one team. It was extracted out of the experiences of Bas Vodde and Craig Larman while Scaling Agile development in many different types of companies, products and industries over the last ten years. There are several case studies available and an upcoming book describing LeSS in detail. 
LeSS consists of the LeSS Principles, the Framework, the Guides and a set of experiments. The LeSS framework is divided into two frameworks: basic LeSS for 2-8 teams and LeSS Huge for 8+ teams. All of these are also available on the less.works website. 
LeSS is different with other scaling frameworks in the sense that it provides a very minimalistic framework that enables empiricism on a large-scale which enables the teams and organization to inspect-adapt their implementation based on their experiences and context. LeSS is based on the idea that providing too much rules, roles, artifacts and asking the organization to tailor it down is a fundamentally flawed approach and instead scaling frameworks should be minimalistic and allowing organizations to fill them in.
events.location: Goodland Building, , 18 Roberts Lane #05-01, Singapore 218297

events.name: Yet Another Two Haskell Talks in May (by Arnauld and Gergo)
events.description: A big thanks to Michał's support so that we could use HackerSpace.SG as a steady base for the meetup. Starting from May, we would try to change to a monthly schedule, We try to arrange the meetup to be at the first Wednesday of each month, since we observe that more RSVP on meetup hosted on Wednesday. Therefore we always welcome speakers willing to share things related to Haskell, no matter it is basic or advanced or lightning talk. Don't hesitate to contact us. For the meetup in May, we would have three haskell talks. First one is Arnaud Bailly share on building startup in haskell. Second one is FPGA synthesis by Dr. Gergő Érdi. We are going to finish with a lightning talk on an alternative description of Haskell packages by Simon Hengel. * Haskell all the way down - building a startup in Haskell Sneak peak of past slide: https://speakerdeck.com/abailly/haskell-all-the-way-down * FPGA synthesis with Kansas Lava * hpack: An alternative format for Haskell packages (lightning talk) # Speakers: Arnaud Bailly: https://github.com/abailly Dr. Gergő Érdi: http://unsafePerform.IO Simon Hengel: https://github.com/sol

events.name: Nurturing Leonardos
events.description: Nurturing Leonardos An international conference Friday 8 and Saturday 9 May 2015 Expression Gallery, Level 4 FREE *There will be no pre-registration for the event. Attendees may sign in when they arrive and seats will be filled on a first-come-first-served basis. In May 2015, ArtScience Museum will host a conference exploring the legacy of history's most celebrated artist and scientist, Leonardo da Vinci (1452-1519). Most studies of da Vinci focus on a specific area of his activity - art, anatomy, technology, studies on water, on flight, and so on. This conference will offer a different point of view, encouraging an exploration of da Vinci's way of thinking and of the cultural landscape, which nurtured him. It will analyse how his interdisciplinary approach, which we now refer to as “systems thinking” and "complexity", remains strikingly resonant for us today, and applied within the fields of art, science, technology, education and foresight. The conference begins with a special edition of ArtScience Museum's monthly performance programme, ArtScience Late (Thursday 7 May), and continues for two full days of discussions on Friday 8 and Saturday 9 May, featuring presentations from within Singapore and around the world, from a range of leading speakers in the fields of history, art, science & technology, education, and futures thinking. It includes keynotes from major names in art history such as Professor Paolo Galluzzi (Italy), as well as dynamic contemporary artists, innovative scientists and technologists, and influential cultural commentators. This conference has been co-convened by Honor Harger and Anna Salaman (ArtScience Museum), and Andrea Nanetti (Nanyang Technological University, School of Art, Design and Media). Thursday 7 May 2015, 7pm – 10pm ArtScience Late will feature a special performance from, our international ArtScience resident, Maurizio Martinucci (TeZ). The show is free, and there will be performances at 8pm and 9pm. For more, see: https://www.facebook.com/events/628941177236899/ Friday 8 May 2015, 10am – 6pm The first day of the conference presents da Vinci and the approach that he took to all of his lines of enquiries. It analyses how da Vinci not only understood the essence of ‘systems’ thinking, but how he also applied this to his inventions, ideas and work generally. We ask, was this approach extraordinary for its time? Was da Vinci different from his renowned contemporaries in this way? To address these questions, the keynote speaker, Professor Galluzzi will present an overview of da Vinci’s life, influences, influencers and projects in this context, and Don Alberto Rocca will explore the educational and cultural contexts of da Vinci’s time and place. We will investigate if there was something within the context of da Vinci’s time which encouraged his thinking and ‘systems’ awareness, or was this a one-off? We ask if there are there other examples of interdisciplinary thinking and approaches throughout history. The day will continue with a reflection on the more recent times and the advent of new media – a marriage of two seemingly quite separate, established disciplines: art and technology, moving the dialogue into the 20th century, and beyond. Confirmed participants: Paulo Galluzzi (Italy) Rev. Dr. Alberto Rocca, Director, Biblioteca Ambrosiana (Italy) David Harvey (USA) Gunalan Nadarajan (USA) Luciano Chessa (USA) Gregory Clancey (National University of Singapore) Margaret Tan (National University of Singapore) Vibeke Sorensen (Singapore) Ruben de la Nuez (Singapore) Isabelle Desjeux (Singapore) Saturday 9 May 2015 The whistle-stop tour through key ‘systems thinkers’ in history from the previous day continues with a day exploring contemporary ‘systems approaches’, specifically addressing the areas. It will cover how science and technology environments might nurture the "Leonardos" of tomorrow and stimulate interdisciplinary working, and look at innovative education and pedagogical methodologies today which will encourage the same. Fittingly, the last session looks to the future. Curated by Forum for the Future, it addresses how complex problems of this time may be solved using multidisciplinary and the ‘systems’, or ‘complexity theory’ approaches. A sub-theme will explore addressing challenges at scale. Confirmed participants: Peng Kian Tan (Singapore) Ei-Leen Tan (Singapore) Veerappan Swaminathan (Singapore) Grace Sai (Singapore) Honor Harger (Singapore) Venka Purushothaman (Singapore) Kenneth Kwok (Singapore) Tong Yee (Singapore) Noorlinah Mohamed (Singapore) Forum For The Future (Singapore) Aaron Maniam (Singapore) Allistair Douglas Yin Shanyang (Singapore) Zhen Goh (Singapore) Justin Pickard (UK)
events.location: ArtScience Museum

events.name: Null Singapore Humla - Write your own burp suite plugins
events.description:
Note: This is a free but an invite only event. If you are selected you will receive venue and other information via e-mail. (Laptop is mandatory for participation) 
 
What is null Humla ?  
Null Humla is a hands on workshop where attendees get to get their hands dirty with red team tools and usually held for 3-4 hours. The humla champion will be helping you in understanding and applying the content to real world scenarios.  
  
Humla Champion: Mohammed A Imran 
About Humla Champion - Mohammed A Imran aka secfigo is senior software security engineer at Autodesk and specializes in vulnerability assessment, penetration testing and static code analysis(SAST). He loves to build infosec communities, share his knowledge with the community  and has organized around 60+ secuirty events for the best null chapter, null hyderabad in India. He now leads null Singapore chapter. 
When not at work, he likes to practise his design skills and fiddle with development frameworks. 
  
Details of the workshop: 
1) Introduction to Burp Extender API 
2) Problems with Jython coercion 
3) Hello world Burp plugin 
4) Build, modify and send HTTP requests and retrieve responses 
5) Hows ProxyListener, HTTPListener different   
6) Automate manual efforts while doing assessments 
           - e.g., Automate the process of modifying the signed requests 
7) Work on any specific scenarios which you want to automate.  
   
Prerequisites: 
Knowledge: Fundamentals of OOPS concepts, basic python skills and some experience with burp suite. 
Hardware: Any dual core machine with 4 GB RAM, minimum 20 GB free space. 
Software: Windows 7 x64/ Any Linux Variant , Java 64 bit, Python 2.7 and Jython Standalone, Burp suite professional or Free version. 
Editor : Notepad++ (preferred) or any editor of your choice ( VIM or emacs anyone ;) )  
  
Useful Links: 
We will use windows as our development platform but any platform should do.  
  
Burp suite - http://portswigger.net/burp/download.htmlJython - 
Jython standalone 2.7rc2 version  - http://www.jython.org/downloads.html  
Python 2.7 - https://www.python.org/downloads/release/python-279/  
Vmware Player for running Samurai or WTE images - https://my.vmware.com/web/vmware/free#desktop_end_user_computing/vmware_player/7_0  
  
Please reach out to me at morpheus@null.co.in or @secfigo if you have any questions regarding the event.
events.location: TBD, , selected individuals will be informed of thevenue, Singapore null

events.name: Data Mining with R (Workshop I)
events.description: Hello everyone, At RUGS, we would like to encourage more people to use R, and to use R to do good statistics. As such, Alex and I are organising a series of tutorials on the top data mining algorithms. The content of the talks will aim to cover a little understanding of the theory, but will mostly focus on examples with R. The 8 - 10 algorithms we aim to cover include: • k-means • SVM • Apriori • Naive Bayes • Random forests and decision/regression trees • EM • kNN • AdaBoost We intend for the sessions to be held on a monthly basis, lasting about an hour or so. The venue will be 237 South Bridge Road. We’ll have to collect SGD 5 a head, but this goes toward the venue and refreshments (not into our pockets =)). We'll collect it at the door on the day itself. The speakers for the talks will be our very own RUGS members. If you are an expert in one of the topics and would like to conduct the session, do let us know! For the first talk, Alex will be speaking about SVM. Here is a short overview of the talk, and a little bit about Alex too About SVM: SVM is nowadays one of the most popular classification algorithms. It is efficient in dealing big data set. It allows us to fit nonlinear classification boundary with kernel methods. Moreover, the combination of penalization and “customized” kernel enable us to introduce prior knowledge into classification. In this R share session, we will quickly go through the theoretical part of SVM, and demonstrate the application with R package “kernlab”. And last but not least, we will show 2 examples to let you feel the power of SVM. About Alex: I am a statistician in HSOR@NHG. I have been studying statistics for 6 years and using R for 6 years. My research areas are statistical learning, computing statistics, data visualization and data science with population health management.
events.location: 237 (http://237.io/), 237 South Bridge Road Singapore 058786

events.name: Truth About Cyber Security Threat & Risk in Singapore
events.description:
This exclusive seminar is a joint effort between Korea IT Cooperation Centre and NSHC. 
This will be the first time, NSHC is releasing top classified information regarding cyber espionage that is happening in Singapore and demo session of various form of attack on Smart Devices. 
This talk is held exclusively for personnel in Cyber Security industry on the following topic; 
  1) Introduction about NSHC 
  2) Cyber Espionage 
-          Cyber Espionage using Back Door Access 
-          Sharing Major Zero Day Vulnerabilities found on WiFi Routers 
  3) Current Threat on Smart Devices 
-          Latest Trend and Status of Mobile Security 
-          Technical Demo on IOS Masque Attack 
-          Technical Demo on IOS Occupied Tools 
-          Technical Demo on Android Malware 
  4) Cyber Threat on SCADA and PLC system 
-          Technical Demo on SCADA and PLC system hacking 
  5) Conclusion 
  6) Q&A
events.location: Korea IT Cooperation Center Conference Room, , 8 Shenton Way AXA Tower #04-01, Singapore 068811

events.name: Lean Beer
events.description: Grab a beer, be merry and have a Lean Coffee style discussion. We will be focusing on the topics that are of interest to you. Anything from Kanban (duh), Scrum, Lean, Lean UX, Lean Startup, Agile practices to issues that you are addressing with the team today. Topic generation will be from 6:30 - 6:45pm. Discussion from 6:45pm onwards Beginners to experts are all welcome!
events.location: Penny Black, 27 Boat Quay, Singapore

events.name: 5th Tableau User Group Singapore Meetup
events.description: Hi Everyone, Based on feedback from the previous meeting, we will be having the next meetup in the evening. We will be starting around 7pm on the 14th of May. Co-working space "The Working Capitol" has generously sponsored one of the workshop rooms for us to organize the 5th Tableau User Group Singapore Meetup The agenda will be as follows. 19:00 Refreshments and Networking 19:25 Welcome and introduction (5 min) 19:30 1st Topic (20min) 19:50 Tableau Announcements / Topics (10min) 20:00 2nd Topic (20min) - Re-viz-it 20:20 3rd Topic (20min) 20:40 Interesting Links, Blogs and Articles (5 min) 20:45 Q&A and Collective Problem Solving (15 min) 21:00 Closing Bring your laptop with Tableau installed, if you have problems, you could show and ask the group, or one-on-one. If you are interested to show your awesome Tableau Visualization, or want to share a really cool trick you found, let us know we can either slot you in for a 10-15 min demo, or we could do it during the Q&A and Collective Problem Solving. One last request : We would like to get to know you a little better. Help us by filling in a quick survey to tell about yourself, and what you would like to see from the Tableau User Group. Singapore Tableau User Group Survey Thanks Richard, Zane and Jimmy TUGS Organizers
events.location: The Working Capitol, 1 Keong Saik Road, Singapore 089109

events.name: Services Workshop - Smart Health coLAB
events.description:
At the Services Workshop on 14 May, we're inviting start-ups, SMEs and corporates to share how they've pulled together technologies and data to address changes in the health space. Here's where you can get a good picture of what Health 2.0 might look like.    
If you're interested in sharing a case study at this workshop, drop us an email here.    
It's going to be an exciting week, so don't miss the Future of Health event and the Data & Tech Workshop that we're also organising. Then, top the week off with the Smart Health Hack Day, where you get to work alongside experts and passionate citizens. Each workshop will have a team formation session, where you can meet other like-minded participants and start forming your teams for the Hack Day!      
PROGRAMME 
Find out more about what's in store for you here.
events.location: 237 South Bridge Rd, , 237 S Bridge Rd, Singapore 058786

events.name: IBM Bluemix @ The Co-Foundry
events.description: Details and Agenda are pending. Agenda: 1900 - 1930 Registration / Networking 1930 - 2000 Introduction to Bluemix 2000 - 2100 Q&A / Networking If you have anything you want to share, please contact me!
events.location: The Co-foundry, Unit 11 Lor 24A Geylang Singapore 398535

events.name: Hack Day - Smart Health coLAB
events.description:
The Smart Health Hack Day on Saturday, 16 May, will be a playground for developers, start-up teams, data scientists, and anyone interested in Smart Health to experiment with data, technologies, APIs, devices, and more to create their own prototypes - solutions that might address the challenge of Health 2.0.    
Come meet passionate people working in digital health, technology gurus and expert developers. Share your experience with the less experienced. Form new connections with like-minded innovators.    
If you're already doing smart things with health applications, please email us. We welcome you to come and do a show-and-tell.    
Don't miss the Future of Health event, and the Data & Tech, and Services Workshops we're also organising as part of the Smart Health coLAB. They're an excellent opportunity to inspire ideas and start forming your teams ahead of the Hack Day.    
PROGRAMME 
Find out more about what's in store for you here.
events.location: 237 South Bridge Rd, , 237 S Bridge Rd, Singapore 058786

events.name: Workshop for Youth
events.description: Since Maker Faire will be a larger scale event this year, we would need the support of Youth! We would like to welcome you to our free workshop on 23rd May 2015 at Science Centre from 2pm to 5pm. This workshop is conducted for you to understand what Maker Faire is all about and if you are interested you can contribute to Maker Faire as Makers or volunteers.
events.location: Science Centre Singapore

events.name: Sunday Showcase
events.description: Sunday Showcase allows visitors unique access to cutting edge projects being undertaken by different tertiary institutions across Singapore. The series invites the creators and their work into ArtScience Museum on a Sunday each month. The creators are on hand throughout the afternoon to talk with visitors about their inventions, their creative process, and to facilitate visitors' interaction with the projects. There is something for everyone in this hands-on, accessible showcase series. 24 May 2015, Sunday, 1pm – 7pm ArtScience Galleries, Level 4 FREE Amplified! The Best of the School of Art, Design and Media Nanyang Technological University Final Year students from the School of Art, Design and Media present a vibrant selection of creative works across and between disciplines, media and technology, including graphic and product design, interactive installations and animation.
events.location: ArtScience Museum

events.location: Microsoft Singapore, One Marina Boulevard, Level 22, Meeting Room

events.name: Ethereum Visits Singapore
events.description: Join us for this Two-day event to learn more about block chain 2.0 technology and how it applies to the real world. We will provide an introduction to block chain technology and it's use cases apart from bitcoin. The second day of the event will be a coding workshop for everyone of all skill levels to participate and see what kind of interesting programs they can come up with on the block chain. George Hallem and Ken Kappler will be speaking on behalf of Ethereum, and we will have live video conferences with a few start ups on the block chain, ie www.provenance.org, DigixGlobal (www.dgx.io), the first smart asset company built on Ethereum's block chain, will also be helping to host the event. Calvin Soh will also be guest speaking. He was a creative director for several mnc ad agencies and is currently a branding and marketing consultant for innovative technologies. Amazing dinner will be served so come with empty stomachs and open minds! Spaces are limited so please sign up for this free and informative event!
events.location: Singapore Management University Administration Building Level 4, 81 Victoria Street

events.name: Ethereum Pub Crawl / Social event
events.description: On Saturday, join us get to meet the community who are interested in blockchain technology and knock back a few drinks together. Ethereum's devs will be gracing this event. This will be an informal gathering of blockchain and tech enthusiasts to network, hangout, ask questions and of course have fun. Looking forward to seeing as many people there! No age limit (just be above 18)! Location TBD, or if anyone has a good spot to recommend please pm me. See you there!
events.location: Level 33, 8 Marina Blvd 33-01 Marina Bay Financial Tower, Singapore

events.name: Hebocon Singapore (Robotics competition for the technically ungifted)
events.description: We will be holding a HEBOCON challenge as part of the South East Asia Makerspace Summit scheduled to be held from 5-7 June 2015. Known as Japan’s "worst robot competition”, the purpose of the HEBOCON event is to find out which crappy robot is the ultimate failure of them all through a sumo-styled wrestling battle. This event will serve as a testbed for the organizers to improve the competition processes leading to the HEBOCON main event in July. Thank you. For more information about HEBOCON, check out the official page at https://www.facebook.com/Hebocon.Official
events.location: OneMaker Group - OMG
